ohms_law.title: Ohm's Law Calculator
ohms_law.description: Calculate Voltage, Current, Resistance, and Power using Ohm's Law.
ohms_law.calculate_for_tooltip: Select the parameter you want to calculate
ohms_law.about_desc: Ohm's Law is a fundamental principle in electricity that relates voltage, current, and resistance in an electrical circuit.
ohms_law.formula_p: P = V × I = I² × R = V² / R

howItWorks.title: How Ohm's Law Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: V = I × R, P = V × I
howItWorks.explanation: Ohm's Law is the foundation of electrical engineering, describing the relationship between voltage, current, and resistance. Voltage equals current times resistance, and power equals voltage times current.
steps: Select the parameter to calculate (Voltage, Current, Resistance, or Power)
Enter the two known values
The calculator automatically computes the unknown value
Review results including power consumption

seoTips: Remember Ohm's Law only applies to linear circuits
Use consistent units (Volts, Amps, Ohms)
Power in Watts helps select properly rated components
Calculate power to avoid exceeding component ratings
commonMistakes: Mixing units (milliamps instead of amps)
Applying Ohm's Law to non-linear components
Neglecting power dissipation calculations
Not accounting for temperature effects on resistance

faqs.question: What's the difference between voltage and current?
faqs.answer: Voltage is the electrical pressure difference (like water pressure), while current is the flow of electrons (like water flow rate). Resistance limits this flow.

faqs.question: Can I use Ohm's Law for AC circuits?
faqs.answer: Yes, but for AC circuits with inductors or capacitors, use impedance (Z) instead of resistance (R).

faqs.question: How do I calculate resistance if I only know power and voltage?
faqs.answer: Use the formula R = V²/P. For example: a 60W bulb at 220V has R = 220²/60 = 807Ω.

voltage_divider.title: Voltage Divider Calculator
voltage_divider.description: Calculate the output voltage of a voltage divider consisting of two resistors.
voltage_divider.input_voltage_tooltip: The electrical voltage applied to the divider
voltage_divider.resistor_1_tooltip: First resistor connected to input voltage
voltage_divider.about_desc: A voltage divider is a simple circuit that converts a large voltage into a smaller one using resistors.
voltage_divider.empty_state: Enter input voltage and resistor values to calculate output voltage
voltage_divider.footer_note: Ensure resistors have sufficient power rating for the calculated dissipation.

howItWorks.title: How the Voltage Divider Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: A voltage divider splits input voltage proportionally based on resistor values. The voltage across R2 equals the ratio of R2 to total resistance multiplied by input voltage.
steps: Enter the input voltage (Vin)
Enter the first resistor value (R1)
Enter the second resistor value (R2)
Get output voltage, current, and power dissipation

seoTips: Use 1% tolerance resistors for sensitive applications
Consider load effect on output voltage
Choose high resistance values to minimize current draw
Verify resistor power ratings to prevent burnout
commonMistakes: Ignoring load resistance effect on output voltage
Using resistors too low causing high power consumption
Not accounting for resistor tolerance in calculations
Using voltage dividers for high current applications

faqs.question: Can I use a voltage divider as a voltage regulator?
faqs.answer: Not recommended because output voltage changes with load. Use a regulator like LM317 for varying loads.

faqs.question: How do I choose appropriate resistor values?
faqs.answer: Choose resistors so that divider current is at least 10x expected load current to minimize load effect.

faqs.question: Does a voltage divider work with AC?
faqs.answer: Yes, but use impedance instead of resistance if there are capacitors or inductors in the circuit.

led_resistor.title: LED Resistor Calculator
led_resistor.description: Calculate the correct resistor value to protect a Light Emitting Diode (LED).
led_resistor.supply_voltage_tooltip: Voltage from the battery or power supply
led_resistor.led_voltage_tooltip: Voltage drop across the LED (typically 1.8V - 3.3V depending on color)
led_resistor.num_leds_tooltip: Number of LEDs connected in series
led_resistor.about_desc: LEDs need a resistor to limit current; without it, the LED may burn out immediately due to excessive current.
led_resistor.empty_state: Enter LED and power supply parameters to calculate resistance
led_resistor.footer_note: Always choose a resistor with a higher Watt rating than the calculated dissipation.
led_resistor.voltage_too_low: Supply voltage is too low for the selected LEDs!

howItWorks.title: How the LED Resistor Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: Calculates the resistor needed to limit current through an LED. Resistance equals the voltage difference (supply minus LED forward voltage) divided by desired current.
steps: Enter the supply voltage (battery or power supply)
Enter LED forward voltage (varies by color)
Enter desired current (typically 20mA)
Specify number of LEDs in series

seoTips: LED forward voltage: Red 1.8-2V, Green/Yellow 2-2.2V, Blue/White 3-3.4V
Use 10-20mA for normal brightness
Choose resistor power rating 50% higher than calculated
For parallel LEDs, use one resistor per LED
commonMistakes: Forgetting to add a resistor, burning the LED instantly
Using wrong LED voltage (varies by color)
Connecting parallel LEDs with a single resistor
Not accounting for resistor power rating (Watts)

faqs.question: Why does LED voltage vary by color?
faqs.answer: Forward voltage depends on semiconductor material. Blue and white LEDs use materials with higher bandgap energy, requiring higher voltage.

faqs.question: What happens if I use a smaller resistor than needed?
faqs.answer: Higher current flows through the LED, reducing its lifespan or burning it instantly. Always use equal or higher resistance.

faqs.question: Can I connect multiple LEDs in series?
faqs.answer: Yes, but ensure total LED voltages are at least 2-3V less than supply voltage for the resistor to work properly.

resistor_color_code.title: Resistor Color Code Calculator
resistor_color_code.description: Determine resistor value based on band colors, or vice versa.
resistor_color_code.num_bands_tooltip: Choose the number of color bands on the resistor
resistor_color_code.about_desc: Bands are read from left to right. The last band (or slightly separated one) represents the tolerance.

howItWorks.title: How the Resistor Color Code Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: Resistors use colored bands to indicate their resistance value. Each color represents a digit (0-9), a multiplier (power of 10), or a tolerance percentage. Reading bands left to right gives the resistance value.
steps: Select the number of bands (4 or 5)
Choose colors for each band from the dropdown
The calculator displays the resistance value
View the tolerance range for the resistor

seoTips: 4-band: 2 digits + multiplier + tolerance
5-band: 3 digits + multiplier + tolerance (precision resistors)
Gold multiplier = 0.1, Silver multiplier = 0.01
Tolerance: Gold = 5%, Silver = 10%, Brown = 1%
commonMistakes: Reading bands in wrong direction (start from the side with bands closer together)
Confusing brown and red, or orange and yellow
Mixing up gold/silver tolerance vs. multiplier bands
Not accounting for tolerance when selecting resistors

faqs.question: How do I know which end to start reading from?
faqs.answer: Start from the end with bands grouped closer together. The tolerance band (gold/silver) is usually slightly separated and read last.

faqs.question: What's the difference between 4-band and 5-band resistors?
faqs.answer: 5-band resistors have an extra significant digit, providing higher precision (e.g., 1% tolerance) compared to 4-band resistors (typically 5% or 10%).

faqs.question: Why do some resistors have no tolerance band?
faqs.answer: No tolerance band indicates 20% tolerance. These are older or very inexpensive resistors rarely used in precision applications.

resistors_parallel.title: Series & Parallel Resistors Calculator
resistors_parallel.description: Calculate total resistance, current, and power for a group of resistors connected in series or parallel.
resistors_parallel.connection_type_tooltip: Choose the type of resistor connection
resistors_parallel.series_formula_1: Total Resistance: R = R1 + R2 + R3 + ...
resistors_parallel.series_formula_2: Current is identical through all resistors
resistors_parallel.series_formula_3: Voltage is distributed according to each resistor's value
resistors_parallel.parallel_formula_2: Voltage is identical across all resistors
resistors_parallel.parallel_formula_3: Current is distributed according to each resistor's value
resistors_parallel.empty_state: Enter voltage and resistor values to see results
resistors_parallel.footer_note: Ensure correct connection type is selected before calculating.

howItWorks.title: How the Series & Parallel Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: Calculates total resistance for resistors in series (add values) or parallel (add reciprocals). Also shows current and power distribution across each resistor.
steps: Select connection type (series or parallel)
Enter the supply voltage
Add resistor values one by one
View total resistance and individual results

useCases: Designing voltage dividers and current sharing
seoTips: Series: same current, voltage divides proportionally
Parallel: same voltage, current divides inversely
Total parallel resistance is always less than smallest resistor
Use 1% resistors for precision voltage dividers
commonMistakes: Using series formula for parallel circuits
Forgetting that parallel resistance is less than any single resistor
Not checking individual resistor power ratings
Mixing series and parallel formulas in complex networks

faqs.question: Why use series resistors?
faqs.answer: Series resistors increase total resistance and divide voltage proportionally. Useful for voltage dividers, current limiting, and creating specific resistance values.

faqs.question: Why use parallel resistors?
faqs.answer: Parallel resistors decrease total resistance, increase current capacity, and provide redundancy. If one fails, the circuit may still work.

faqs.question: How do I analyze a circuit with both series and parallel?
faqs.answer: Simplify step by step: first combine parallel groups into single equivalents, then add series resistances. Repeat until you have one equivalent resistance.
